text: Hello fellow travellers, Trying to organise an inital holiday with my wife and 2 children (8and 6) hoping to get some view and opinions of hiring a car and doing airbnb or getting a motorhome as we intend to do the full lap of Italy. I am a very confident manual driver but asking regads access to road with a bigger vehicle and safety your belongings and motorhome. Thankyou in advance for your input appreciate your attention.

comments.comment_text: I am a very confident driver including larger vehicles and would only consider something like a motor home in Tuscany but it would be difficult park when visiting many towns we saw. We had two daughters (10 and 13) with us. Trains and boats are the way to go just pack light and stay in AirBnBs with washers long enough for clothes to dry. Good luck with your planning.

I wouldn't want something like a motorhome in Italy. Especially in regions like Tuscany where the roads are very twisty and narrow with lots of hills. Our group had an SUV and a minivan and that's a big as I would want
I saw a post from someone that had a small motorhome and drove around, they said lots of places were very tight so larger one might be hard. If you can fit in a small one maybe.

text: Looking for shoe recommendations that are appropriate for walking the streets of Italy. Want something comfortable, stylish, and ideally open-toed for warm weather. What shoe type? Or shoe brands?

comments.comment_text: I lived in my Skechers for almost 2 weeks- super comfy and no aching feet at the end of the day
Aetrex Jillian cushiony with arch support

My Birkenstock sandals were the clear winner for me when it came to sandals in Italy.
I love my Naots and Sorel sandals but I have a narrow foot and felt like the cobblestones were a bit tougher to navigate with the Naots and Sorels, despite overall comfort and sturdiness of the sandals. Birkenstocks were my go to.
Just find a pair that you are comfortable walking in at home..... They will work in Italy too. Most people wear Birkenstock or runners.
Sketchers every time
Sketchers
I wore Teva sandals all over Rome. Also Sketchers sneakers.
Taos brand sandals
Abeo brand - super cute and comfy
Ecco Soft 7s. not a single blister or sore foot!!! with 1000s of steps! Taking em back with me in September!
Sofft and Bionica
Vionic…..best stylish sandals and so, so comfortable
Sorel sandals.

SAS … walked for miles and miles. Fully adjustable…grea
t if your feet swell. Never ever got sour feet. Sketchers are fab also more than 1/2 the price.
Ecco sandals
Here now in Sorrento Italy, wearing my Birkenstocks every day! I have 3 different pairs and all are great for the cobblestone streets and comfortable!
I wore Tory Burch white sneakers and my feet are killing me with blisters! Lol don’t wear them 🤣
This is my 5th time here and the first time I brought Birkenstocks and will now be my go to shoe.
Fit flops. Wore them daily for up to 20K steps

My Keen sandals were great on the cobblestones in the rain. I just walked right through the puddles!
I have a pair of Moshulu hiking sandals. They are fantastic. I also go i to the water with them

comments.comment_text: Can U share which river cruise company you went through please? I know many companies have different options. Thx
That's a lot of climates ... I would pack a lot of clothes as I love fashion

Onion Layers! That's how we call here in Italy wearing multiple layers of clothing due to different weather conditions. Most of the areas you are about to visit are windy and wet. Also if you are going to start your journey from Southern countries you should be in time to bathe and enjoy summer weather so keep in mind to bring with yourself the swimsuit too!

text:
After planning our trip for last 2 years, 6 weeks ago I got plantar fascia and foot spurs.
So 2weeks ago had cortisone needleand pain went until yesterday....we leave in 3weeks and im back in pain again, any suggestions to help it so I can walk freely in Italy 😵‍💫😵‍💫

comments.comment_text: Get custom made orthotics. They were a game changer for me!

Stretch those calves! PF is caused by tight calf muscles. Anti inflammatory meds around the clock for the week/week and a half if your doctor approves, roll bottom of your foot with frozen water bottle, wear orthotics in your tennis shoes, don’t walk bare foot. I also got ART (active release therapy) through my chiropractor. It took some time to heal for me, but was able to avoid surgery after battling it for a couple of years. Hokas are my best shoe. Go to a running shoe store and have your gait analyzed. They can also give you a recommendation for a shoe that fits/works best for your gait. So if you pronate or supinate or have a neutral foot, they can have you try on different shoes to see which feel best. Good luck! This may take some time to heal.
Ive got the same bloody painful had it for months and sorry to say the jab didnt work the only thing that easies the pain is a bag of frozen peas on it

Get a Fasciitis Fighter to stretch the foot and calves every day, I’m taking one away with me. It’s super light, effective and easy to use. I’ve been using it in Pilates class so know what to do.

https://
fasciitisfighter
.com.au/
Chiropractor
I found that 2 shots were required. Similar experience to you in that the first shot gave relief for 10-14days, the second shot worked a treat and I’m over 5 years no pain 😊
Make sure footware has arch support nothing flat
iontophoresis is what l had done for my plantar fasciitis it’s never came back

Ask for another cortisone injection
Sometimes a second is needed
Do lots of calf stretches
I mildly fractured my 5th metatarsal before going on to the UK/Ireland in June. Purchased Hoka Bondi tennis shoes on the advice of my ortho. My foot did really well. Saved the trip!
Naproxen and rest
Insoles, arch supports, 600mg Tylenol, weight loss
Good shoes and some corticosteroid Treatment
Solonpas tape on top of foot.

Buy a pair of Hokas they are the best for plantar fasciitis
My hubby is a podiatrist and tells all his patients to wear these

Don't k ow your age but I spent a fortune over 2 yrs on doctors,steroid
injections,phys
ios etc,then discovered its a major symptom of menopause.3 weeks on HRT pain almost gone.Wish I knew earlier

I went to Fleet Feet shoe store and they fitted me with a Brooks Glycerin shoe. They do an analysis of your feet. I was able to walk Portugal/Spain for 22 days pain free! They have support and cushioning to make the shoe so comfortable. Just know they are $$$ but worth it for me. Good luck.

You will not be normal. You will need orthotic arch supports made by a podiatrist or foot specialist. You can sleep on your stomach with your feet over the end of the bed so the muscles do not stretch overnite
You can do exercises facing the stairs, with your toes in the tread, dropping your heels as low as you can 3 reps of ten, and there are various others, including rolling tennis balls with the arch of your foot. Do your internet research and find what works for you. If you ignore this, you will try to stand up one day and find yourself in incapa itating pain unable to move.
There are many exercises you can do see a good podiatrist idid & helped heaps !

My podiatrist sent me to PT. Said stretching ankle and calf muscles was the key. My muscles were as hard as a rock. Three weeks of PT and dry needling and cupping muscles were normal. I wore brooks tennis shoes (supportive tennis shoe) with a custom insert. All my outfits when walking was worn with the tennis shoe. I hated the bulky tennis shoes but it saved my feet. Most days I did 20k steps. I also continued the stretching exercises. Resting feet as much as possible and Tylenol. Fortunately my trip included 3 days at sea, on those days I stayed off my feet except for meals.

Youtube how to wrap your foot for plantar fasciitis. I am a dog walker and had a severe case. If you can learn to take it, it takes so much pressure off your heel/arch. Find the one that tapes around your foot and back around your heel. Good luck!
I started taking magnesium and vit D it has helped alot as well as a good pair of walking shoes.

My husband had this. Nike Air max trainers! You need support under the arch of your foot. You won’t wear anything else when you have tried these. Don’t bother with the injections again. Trust me, but sone. My husband doesn’t have it anymore.
Stretch those calves! Every day. Twice a day. Hang your heel over the edge of a step and let it drop as far as you can. Feel the stretch! Do it over and over.

Great tips! I found good compression socks helped with my brooks tennis shoes. Even when you don’t want to wear sneakers…do it. Forget the cute shoes and go with comfort. I did find a cute block heel of Taos sandals for sundresses that I can wear periodically to dinner, but not long walks.

Find the sore/tender spot located in your CALF. You’ll feel it immediately when you press it. Massage that spot very gently several times a day using a circular motion, like you are gently undoing a knot.
Have you seen a podiatrist? Prescribed orthotics were a necessity for my healing.
I get very good results from cortisone patches
Go to a podiatrist and get some orthotics for your shoes. I can recommend a good one
Try orthofeet.com. They specialize in all kinds of foot issues.
Head right back to your doc, explain the situation and have him reinject
Hoka shoes helped with mine

1)Dump your basket of missing socks (30 socks)
2) while sitting, pick up each sock individually with your toes and drop them into the empty basket
3) repeat twice a day
By the weekend you’ll never know you had it!
It’s been 15 years for me since I did this and has never came back. 😊
Reflexology helps as well as comfrey lotion on the spur
I have it too. Get up early and stretch your feet. Once I get going I am fine. Search it on Amazon there are a lot of things you can buy to help.

There are different types of cortisone, some are long lasting like 9 months slow release.
I suffered badly for years.
Get some compression calf massagers and take with you.
Get a pair of Birkenstocks.
And some magnesium numbing spray.
Go to pod Dr and get him to show you how to strap.
Orthotics
Get birkenstalks. They saved my daughter.
Insoles helped me!
My doctor gave me a boot to sleep with and it worked fast. Yours should have recommended certain brands of shoes too.

Kinetic tape there arch bands and compressions socks for arch and ankle you can use as well. Good arch support in shoes all the time. Search on Amazon. Stock up with a few before you leave. The taping works very well and it stays on for days. You can order that tape online on Amazon as well.

This is great. Use daily even if feet aren’t hurting and will help

Much cheaper that the online ones and does the same thing. Just google the exercises online.
That's painful use orthotics and cold water bottle
Shoe inserts helped with mine somewhat
Stretch every morning

I had it too. Just get foot exercises from the podiatrist and have them strapped for a couple of weeks by a podiatrist too.
Then walk small distances and gradually work up.
Have support insoles in your supportive shoes and don’t wear any other shoes than walking shoes.
Get good shoes…Vionic, Taos, etc. wear them ALL the time NO barefoot!
Super feet inserts, Hoka Bondi 8s, & Hoka recovery slides in the house. Don’t go barefoot. Problem solved immediately.

Vionics…sneaker
s & sandals
See a neuromuscular therapist for massage and exercises. It helped me and has never returned. Enjoy Italy!
Zcoil shoes!! They work!
Hoka shoes are the best but go to the Foot store- they will know what best suits your needs

I did not read all the other comments because I just don’t have time. I don’t think three weeks is enough time to correct this problem before your trip, but it’s worth a try. ￼
1. Get a pair of Clark shoes or a pair of Birkenstocks or a pair of Brooks walking/
running shoes. These brands were approved by the gal who CURED my plantar fasciitis. Wear just that one pair of shoes for the time left before your trip and wear them while on your trip. I don’t care what the occasion is, only wear that one pair of shoes.￼ No heels!

2) Use either an arch pad or support inside the shoe of the affected foot; I liked the Dr Frederick kind. The wrap felt good around my arch.

3)
DONT GO BAREFOOT. EVER.

4)Before your foot hits the floor in the morning, take a stretchy band wrapped under your foot and stretch by straightening your leg up into the air and flexing your foot (toes pointing toward your shin)

5) put your shoe on before getting out of bed. No exceptions.

6) exercise the foot 3-4x day. Stand on the ball of your foot on the edge of a stair w your heel off the step. Hang onto something. Slowly lower your heel until it’s below the step, then, reverse and come up on the ball of your foot with your heel as high above as you can go. Slowly repeat 5-10x.

7) ICE the foot.

8)massage the sore area of your foot using maximum pressure. Yes, it will hurt. But you need to STRETCH that tight plantar area. If you can’t do it yourself, ask a loved one for their help.
Order would be stretches, exercises, massage, ice.

Good luck. I wouldn’t wish this condition on anyone. Took me 3 months to cure my case of it but once I did it has not returned in 8+ years.
Gel shoe inserts helped me and I made sure I stretched morning and night plus the ball exercise. I also bought a sandal that's plantar fasciitis friendly from Amazon.

Rebook. Plantar fasciitis is hell, I have custom made orthotics, and it took many months to get rid of that pain….don’t compromise your trip….just my two cents….I would personally wait until I was out of pain, you will likely be walking a lot….

I experienced something similar recently. I also got a cortisone shot before leaving for Italy to help with the pain. It aggravated it first but I realized that the more I walked the easier it got. I only wore Hoka bondi sneakers and bionic sandals. Ice at the end of the day helps with the swelling. I had a fantastic trip (1400 steps a day). I hope you have a great trip!
I wore wedges when I had PF and I had no pain.
Wear toe spacers at night, Birkenstocks during the day.
Nothing helped me until I started wearing Oofos around the house. It’s amazing the difference in my pain level.

I’ve had the same issue and I empathize with this discomfort. I’ve gone to my orthopedist/
podiatrist and had them tape my foot for the plantar fasciitis and I’ve had them show me how to do it myself. The tape can stay on fro 5-7 days before you need to re-do (you’ll need to buy the role of tape at the doctor- it’s $25/roll. Also, every night, elevate and ice. Also, no fliplops or sandals- stick with the best cushioned show you can find (Altra sneakers are my go-to).
Good luck it takes a very long time for it to go away

My podiatrist said sleeping with my boot will keep everything stretched and toes pointing up . . .
the thought was when sleeping, the toes end up pointing down and the muscles shorten . . . the pain comes from stretching out the heel muscles. When the muscles are already stretched, there is very little pain to get warmed up!!

I am going around same time as you. I had bone spur removed in January but now I need fusion but not until after trip. I am going for injections first week of September but my dr told me to wear supportive shoes only. I have two pair of Hokas and my feet do not hurt when I have these on. I feel your pain literally. I also have arthritis in my toes. Get you some supportive shoes, wear now to break in and I also use Voltarin cream. Have a wonderful time

For the heel spur I found that a wrap around the arch helps. The idea is that the foot is even all the way so the heel doesn’t get all the pressure.

Maybe another shot right before you go? I know it stinks but believe it will work out. I broke my arm the week before I left to go to Italy in June and it worked out…it had to!

I bought new walking shoe for our trip at the end of September. They are extremely comfortable and they help with feet problems. The company is called OrthoFeet. They are a little expensive, but they have extra insoles for plantar fasciitis. I am going to order another pair in the upcoming weeks and I talked my husband into getting one. Good luck and I hope this helps
Oofos and hokas and roll your foot with lacrosse ball

I had the same problem and went to Scheels sporting good store. They have a computer driven arch support device. You stand on it and it gives an amazing amount of information but more importantly, it tells you which inserts you should use. These inserts took care of my pain. They also recommended. On Cloud shoes and the problem went away for me. ￼ Good luck on your trip. ￼

I have the same issues. I worked with the physiotherapist
for three months prior to my trip so that I could walk. He used shockwave therapy for the most part. He did get me walking and I was able to do the trip with minimal issue, but it took some time, some daily ibuprofen and Voltaren. I iced as much as I could in the evenings and had supportive shoes on. He did not recommend orthotics. ￼￼
For walking I highly recommend Oofos. They were the only shoe I could walk in when I had PF.

I’ve had pf and i feel your pain. I did go to PT and did all kinds of exercises, it was ok. What really helped (and theory) me was long hikes and walking on unlevel ground. Start by walking on landscaping rock. It helps strengthen different muscles in your foot. Remember there are many many bones in your foot. they’re there for a reason, get them moving. Walking on flat ground is repetitive motion that can lead to carpal tunnel

Have plantar fasciitis as well. I wear Ryka or bionic shoes always. Sometimes I have to wear an ankle brace or plantar fasciitis brass. Look on copper fit. So horrible! Sad the cortisone injection doesn’t last longer too! Good luck!
Steroids oral, might have to be on them for the entire trip, tapering down at the end.
Have your doc prescribe a steroid pack

The walking will help, always wear decent, closed in shoes, no thongs, strappy sandals, thin soled sneakers, or really thin soled flats, doesn't matter how 'cute' they are. And never bare feet inside. Enjoy your trip.

No more shots!!! The orthopedic doc should be able to provide you with a vigorous daily stretching program that will alleviate the pain! Invest in some shoes from Mephisto (expensive but worth it) and a good pair of ASICS with arch supports in them. Definitely use the frozen bottle of water a couple of times a day.

I was seeing my GP on an unrelated matter when I mentioned I had PF. She said she had as well but now wore a particular shoe that relieved / cured it. She said she had spent hundreds of dollars on different shoes until she found the ones that worked for her. She said even the same brand of shoe in a different style didn’t work, only these particular ones. I went straight out and bought them and have not had a problem with pain from day one. I wore them all day every day and after a couple of months I slowly transitioned to my other shoes for short periods of time and now only wear them around the house occasionally. No pain. They aren’t very attractive. Maybe you could colour change or embellish them. Google SAS Shoes. Good luck with all the tips here and the right shoes.
BEG for another injection - cortisol injections not $$$ incase insurance denies for being too soon.
Orthotics and New Balance tennis shoes that my doctor recommended for my feet were a life savers, no problems since and have walked all over Europe 3 times since.

I was in pain for over one year with plantar fasciitis and then I started wearing OluKai Ohana Women's Beach Sandals in the house and when I go out and the pain went away. I bought them after google searching the best shoes for plantar fasciitis. It’s worth trying for the next few weeks before heading to Italy. I wear them most of the time and then put on my running shoes for walking the dogs.

My PF started when I was in Europe probably 25 years ago, and I didn’t know what was happening, just knew I had terrible pain that made it hard to walk! At that time I never got out of bed before taking ibuprofen, and took it religiously during the day. Knowing what I know now, I would continue the ibuprofen , and add a shoe insert. Could you get something from the Good Feet Store that could help in the short term?

Well I had same thing & it took 2 shots, so I would inquire about that but do it just a few days before you leave. Get good tennis shoes that have a good cushioned sole in them and take something with you for pain. For me it also helps that I only wear shoes with good arch support as well.

I have that issue if I go barefoot at all, even at night at home. Definitely wear the boot daily and take an anti inflammatory drug. Also, always have shoes on to ensure you’re getting proper support. Make sure you take really good sneakers on vacation. No cute but unsupportive sandals or flip flops. I know it stinks, but more important not to have pain!!

See if a chiropractor or sports therapy office does EPAT therapy in your area. My chiropractor does this treatment in his office. It has been reported to help with plantar fasciitis. Insurance doesn’t cover the cost but I have received this treatment for a few different issues and have had excellent results after a few sessions.

Biofit by Orthofeet shoes worked wonders for me. They are cute too. I had tried all the things mentioned here (custom inserts, boot at night, steroids... nothing worked). As an RN I did 12 hour shifts and by the end of the shift I couldn't stand walking. Honestly these shoes were lifesavers for me.
Arch support shoes or sneakers stretching

I am leaving for Italy in 2.5 weeks and I understand. I got pf 12.27.2022 and I joined the plantar fasciitis Facebook group and got tons of great ideas.

I wear brooks ghosts sneakers and will probably never wear flip flops. I do stretches and icing and taping.

I am taking sneakers and some sandals and crocs to Italy.

Hi! I’m planning to visit Riva del Garda in late September this year. What are your suggestions on best towns to visit, cool activities to do, and the best places to eat at?

We are foodies and also enjoy any activities with water, history, art, shopping, etc.😊

Thanks in advance!

Sarah Michelle

comments.comment_text:
Tenno, a small Town also with a small lake !
Also Malcesine, Limone!

Riva is one of my favourite place in Italy.
The area is full of sport activities, like bicycle paths, climbing, windsurf and so on.
Then there is the “cultural” part. There are ferries that help you move from Riva to the other villages of the Garda. I suggest to visit Malcesine, Sirmione, Lazise, Bardolino and Limone.
If you are into wine and spirits you are in the right place, just behind the city there is the so called “Valle dei laghi”.
You’ll find a lot of winery.
It’s the Nosiola’s area and there are some really nice producers.
I suggest you to download the FIVI app, it’s an association of small producer a trough our app it’s possible to see which winery is closer to you and plan your tasting.
Also grappa is a huge thing in the area. Several distillery up there closer to Trento. Check out Pisoni or Santa Massenza.
A place that I love really much is the castle on the Toblino Lake.
Is like a fairy tale place.
It was owned by the local social winery, now there is a restaurant inside. I don’t know if it is good, but the place deserve a visit.
If you are into food I suggest you a visit to Lunelli shop, in Sarche.
It’s like a small grocery shop, but with a lot of typical stuff. It’s a classic. Try speck and “salsa dell’orso”

www.alcardellin
o.it, www.laverandare
staurant.it or www.locandadelb
enaco.com - and if you´re looking for something special and authentic ( and if you have a car) www.agriturcalv
ola.it ( try the speciality of the area: carne salada ) - in the mountains with view of the lake - also check out Lago di Tenno and the nice villages Rango, Mezzano or the medieval village Canale di Tenno or the Varone waterfall

If you are foodies there are two Restaurants in Riva that are a MUST: https://
www.laberlera.it
/it and https://
www.ristoranteal
volt.com/. They need to be reserved well in advance. I agree with all the other suggestions but I would also add a trip to the beautiful lake Ledro that in a two-hour walk it can all be seen

Google Cinque Terre card. It includes discounts for up to 2 days of hiking access and up to 3 days of unlimited train travel through all CT towns and between Levanto and La Spezia. There are also some buses included, free wifi, some museums and toilets.

Good for you for asking what everyone REALLY does want to know! Here are a few tips I've picked up - hope they help: (1) Accommodations - if you can stay outside the city center (Rome, Naples, Venice, Florence, etc), you are likely to save $$ but consider the cost of getting around to the sites you want to see as well. I prefer to drive outside of the cities, so vacation rentals have been great. There are SO many to choose from (if you look early) and the prices are typically very good. Decide on your criteria (AC? view? remote/
not remote, parking, etc) and search. Most Italian rentals have a "Name" (i.e. "Maria's Bella Vista"). Google the NAME and you can often find the owner's website. When you book directly with the owner, you often save 10 - 40% and the communication is usually excellent. DO read plenty of reviews (on other sites) first though to be comfortable with what you are getting AND confirm the cancellation policy. I have found most owners to also be very helpful with recommendations of things to do and see off the beaten path. When we were in Tuscany in May, the owner of our villa arranged for 2 women from Lucca to come to the house for a cooking class. Not only was it convenient and cost less than had we booked it through a website, it was the most AMAZING night of our trip - the owner brought his own private wine to share and we all sat around the table enjoying the huge meal and conversation for hours. You can't get that in a pricey hotel. (2) Unless you are going in the VERY busy season (summer), wait until a couple weeks before the trip to book a rental car - prices will be significantly less than booking early. To be on the safe side, I often book early to be certain I have what I want but only book with free cancellation. If the prices drop a lot, rebook. (3) And speaking of that, consider going in November - March when prices are much better, crowds are down, and the weather is still usually pretty darn good. (4) On my last three trips to Italy, I have paid around $50 for my flight (front row, main cabin, with 2 checked bags included and lots of perks out of a mid-market airport) - BECAUSE I use my airline credit card for everything and pay it off each month (you usually get 50,000 miles just for applying and using the card right away). No foreign exchange fees AND I get bonus miles for everything. Yes, it costs me $99/year BUT it includes free trip insurance coverage AND free CDW master rental coverage for the car - those two things alone saved me over $350 on my upcoming trip - and the flight would have been $1450 if I didn't use miles. It makes saying "Yes, I think I'll go back to Italy" easy!! (4) Everything in Italy is gorgeous - and so much of it is free to see!! Here are a few of my favorites: (A) In Assisi - the entire village is a wonder. You can spend a day just slowly going from one end to the other enjoying the incredible views and the absolute peace of the place. Plenty of inexpensive shopping and restaurants - and all of the churches, including the magnificent Basilica of San Francesco - which rival most museums - are FREE. (B) Cortona: the village is small and lovely and easy to traverse BUT continue UP the hill to Hermitage "Le Celle" the 13th century Franciscan monastery. There is a large parking lot and it is free to enter and wander around this magnificent site in complete peace. The monks are present but silent, and you won't see them. (C) Saturnia: The hot springs are beautiful and relaxing - open 24/7/365 and FREE. (D) Colle di Val d'Elsa - check out the Parco Fluviale (just google it - it's gorgeous!). (E) Madonna della Corona Sanctuary (Spiazzi, near Lake Garda) - it costs nothing to park and walk down the hill to this spectacular church built into the side of the cliff on Monte Baldo. However, you may opt to pay 1.5 euros to catch the shuttle back UP the hill 😉. (5) There are also great experiences you can have for next to nothing: like riding bikes around the city wall in Lucca (2 euros)! (6) For booking major sites, vineyard tours, ferries, etc. whenever possible, use the official site (i.e. The Vatican Museums, San Marco's, etc). Much more affordable and less likely to be cancelled at the last minute. OKAY - this post is too long already so I'll stop and just wish you a great, memorable trip. Don't sweat the small stuff - because it is ALL good!! You can have a fabulous trip without breaking the bank and never feel like you missed out.

I hear you!! Yes!!!!!
It is absolutely possible to have a fabulous experience in Italy without spending ridiculous amounts on (material) 'stuff'!
We are in Italy right now, travelling for 6 & half months in total - nearly one month of which is in Italy.
We are 52 & 53 years old, and backpacking, kind of.
Yes, we are carrying backpacks the entire time, and we are taking trains & buses, but we are staying in comfy AirBnB's. We are walking a lot!
We buy coffee and cornètto(croiss
ant) every morning, because why wouldn't you? 😋
Then we have either lunch or dinner at a restaurant, always with local vino or beer. If we're hungry in between, there are plenty of markets for the most delicious fresh apricots, cherries, peaches etc. We are having awesome EXPERIENCES, a balance of exploring natural beauty in the countryside, interspersed with city historical and cultural experiences, and yes, some tourist haunts. The balance of all of this is great for our mental health, as well as our travel budget (ie, when the cities/crowds are too much, the peace of the mountains and countryside is a welcome retreat!)
Yes, refill your water bottle, find local markets for one meal a day (beer & vino are much cheaper in the markets too)
Our itinerary has been:
Pisa - 1 night
Cinque Terra - 3 nights
La Grazie - 2 nights
Montepulciano - 4 nights (it was our base for 4 days, we hired a car and explored the Tuscany area)
Firenze - 3 nights ( I could easily spend 3 months here!)
Verona - 2 nights (highly recommend Opera at the arena!! We bought the cheapest seats and it was awesome!)
Bolzano - 2 nights (the cable car up the mountain was incredible!)
Villanders - 5 nights of hiking in the Dolomites (just arrived today...it's gorgeous!!!)
Trieste - 1 night (our entry to Slovenia via ferry)
We paid for all of our airfares and accommodation as we planned/booked 6 months ago, we also paid some of our train & bus tickets in advance if we needed them locked in early (prices increase closer to the travel dates).....we are budgeting an average of less than $200 Australian dollars per day for the two of us while we are here; some days are less, depending on meals and entry fees...which allows us a very occasional splurge along the way (I bought a gold piece in Firenze). I am a bit of a shopper at home, but here my mindset is " oh crap, do I want to carry it for 6 months??" NO! 😅
Ultimately, we are sticking to our budget, but having a fantastic time! 😀
It's definitely possible 💕 Get out there and embrace it!

Stay in the next town from the main centre where public transport is good, we’ve often preferred these towns, they’re quieter, and accom is cut in half (eg. Sant’Agnelo to Sorrento).
Fitness to walk will save a fortune, and you’ll see so much more of each place!

Don’t stay in the city centre. We stayed in Montecatini Terme and trained into Florance. Was about €6.
We never once scrimped on food but found breakfast at the hotel was enough to see you through until afternoon and then a late dinner. We only ate in Florence once and the price comparison was crazy!

We cooked many meals esp breakfast in our airbnb so we could head out quickly and lunches were either home made or a quick pizza slice or panini. We found huge delicious panini that served 2 next to colesseum for 6 euro that were shareable. We wouldn’t do too many sit down meals unless we had ample time but food is an easy way to save money. Second use of public transportation!
We never used any taxis or ubers just figured out public transit and walked. The local grocery stores like carrefour express are fantastic and reasonable and open 24:7 .

I travel to many places and I don’t kill my budget because I travel during off times (cruises in January to S. America), civil unrest (Morocco after the Arab Spring), and anytime after some sort of terror attack. I also dress like locals and try to learn the language, so I can do what they do, eat where they eat, etc. I stay in hostels not hotels, and I am super low maintenance when traveling because I’m a teacher and I don’t have gobs of cash. My friend and I took a trip from my house in England to Morocco for 4 days for $400 each including airfare and hostels.
“Free” walking tours - young just tip the guide, YouTube “free things to do in (city)” or “(city) in less than €20 a day” - loads of ideas! Book hotels and trains ahead of time for discounts.
Love this post! I travel to Italy from South Africa whenever I can but the exchange rate is 20:1 so it’s not a five star all the way experience but always so loved ❤️

Drink the water from the taps and refill its free. Eat outside the main areas, buy street food way cheaper. Stay at reputable air bnb way cheaper. And lots of places like churches and gardens, parks u can see for free.
I’m budget conscious as well. Which is why I’ve traveled fairly often :)

I am the queen of frugal Italian travel! I feel like the best, authentic meals and accommodations were unexpected and cheap. For me, the smaller villages are the best, but when seeing the bigger cities, I book my accommodations about 30 minutes walking or a bus/train stop away from the main area I want to see. As for as meals, i always walk a few blocks away from the busy attractions. You can have “once in a lifetime trip” without breaking the bank. Especially if you don’t need high end.
Following

Do your own itinerary..get cheapest return flight to Italy and start from there. You can travel within Italy via train, plane, bus..all cheap. Eat locally, wine is cheaper than water. Do not take tours, except for Rome, do not use travel agents either.
Following

I pride myself on finding deals lol
I live for cheap travel hacks 😃
Elizabeth Colleen Fowler

If you're going to Tuscany, stay in a real farmhouse at Pacina in Castelnuovo Berardegna. It's a working farm! They make olive oil, wine, and pasta. It's only $100/ night in March, and we took day trips to Assisi, Siena, and a couple other places. There are many places you can drive to. We took a pasta - making class in Florence ($49 each) I've been making pasta! The one thing we did that was expensive was a truffle hunting tour ($149 each), but I highly recommend it. I would do it again in a heartbeat. The couple, Daniele, and Daniella have 3 dogs. You learn about truffles first, thyme you go hunting, and when you return, lunch is waiting. Unlimited truffles!! They also make wine and truffle oil. What we took home is almost gone. Let me know if you would like any of the information.
Curious - what are your flight prices for upcoming Italy trips and from where? Our quote shocked me. Seems high 🤷🏼‍♀️
Following
Name of the company please?
Mindy Jo could you please send me the company’s info too? Thank you!

If anyone is interested I can share info on a private hotel that’s a great place and price even though it was listed as hostel.
Was pleasantly surprised!

I travel solo on a budget and it's cheaper for me to spend a month in Rome including airfare than a month in Australia. I book accommodation on booking dot com and generally find places with breakfast included. I also book for a week or more as the rates can be more reasonable for a longer stay. Lunch I'd get a panini or buy something from the supermarket. Dinner I'd wander the back streets and find little places that were lovely food and less tourist prices. Rick Steves audio is great for tours, I really don't like guided tours anyway. Also, free entry on the first Sunday of the month saves money. I tend to wander the streets, go into churches, sit and people watch. I did a month in Rome for AUD $4800 last year. This year it's AUD $5200 as I'm catching some trains

If from UK...get the bus outside naples Airport directly to the hydro foil..it goes through Naples centre so u see a bit. Arrival by water at sorrento is the only way to arrive. Book the bus tour from the bus station to Almalfi and positano. For Capri book the boat trip in Sorrento to take u over do a swim tour around the island seeing the green lagoon as the blue one will be booked and waste alot of time. Hop off into Capri for three hours have lunch back on your boat. Transfer back from boat to hotel. Train to Pompei and herculiem. Pick up a tour when there. At herculean train station pick up a tour bus up to Mount versusius. Ride the local bus bus from positano if u want to stay a bit later on the beach. Ride the little train around Sorrento. Get a pizza in Naples enroute to Airport. Cio!
If you get bread on your table refuse it, otherwise it gets added on your bill and they don’t tell you. Unless you want it of course
We made sure to walk as much as possible. We had 4 elementary aged children and we would walk at least 10 miles/day. Gelato was our treat!

1) Go with a friend so you can split the cost of everything. 2)Reserve accommodations away from touristy areas.
3) Go with the flow rather than reserve everything ahead of time. I reserve accommodations for the first few days then decide what I’ll do after I arrive. I often take recommendations
from other travelers I meet along the way. Sounds risky but I have done this many times, even with children in tow.
4) Take public transit or walk when you don’t have your luggage with you.
5) Don’t be afraid to travel without your kids🤣.

We have done free city walking tours all over Europe. Just google free city tour and the city name. They are great for a bit of history and, because they are often locals, they give great recommendations
on eateries, other things to see etc

Here are my tips, some great ones on here:
- If you eat out, just get a main course. They make more money on starters and desserts and then you end up buying more drinks
- For dessert, leave the restaurant and get a gelato instead. Just the one flavour in a non fancy cone
- Avoid any eating or drinking on central piazzas
- Take limited luggage and do a wash in your Airbnb
- Avoid guided tours
- Take public transport
- Watch people from parks
- Wander around a food market
- Supermarkets are cheap and good quality
- Go for a walk in the country
- Go for a passeggiata in the evening
- If you have kids and they are picky eaters, let them eat beforehand and have breadsticks so they don’t waste a meal they don’t eat.
- Some churches are free to visit
- Expensive, iconic places are free to photograph from outside

Hi. Sorry you’ve had negative replies from other groups. I’ve been going to Italy for years & here are my top tips for saving €s:
Stand at the bar for your coffee. Eat at lunchtime & don’t be embarrassed to share a course. Around 6pm most bars in Italy put out little snacks at the bar complimentary with a drink. Use public transport. Book direct with an hotel & negotiate a discount - they pay the booking.conms & other agents 10/15% commission. Eat away from city sights. Do free walking tours. Shop for water/
essentials at supermarkets not deli’s as these are dearer. Go out of season. Learn some Italian words:phrases. Go to mass to see inside the cathedrals for free. Enjoy your trip & safe travels.

My husband and I try to share an appetizer and an entrée. Only 2 restaurants haven’t allowed this. We also have a quick, on-the-go lunch (pizza, focaccia, sandwich) and have breakfast at the hotel/bnb. We also try to stop at a grocery store or convenience shop and pick up snacks and light meals.

Take the bus from FCO to Rome Termini. It was about 6 euros per person. If you bought round trip it ended up being approx 10 euros per person. For us as a group of four that difference between bus and train or cab was the price of a few trips for gelato!

I would look at monasterystays.
com. I have used them a few times with good results. You can stay in really popular areas for much cheaper. I have found them to be clean and safe. Be aware that some have curfews that are very strict. I make sure mine don’t just in case dinner runs long. Happy travels!!

I don’t leave my hotel hungry - that can be trouble when you settle for the first cafe and pay whatever to eat. I like to scout then find a good place. My husband and I split entrees - it’s too much food.

Why hate nessages??
Report to.admin.
40 ppl got booted out yesterday from another group am in...Admins got fed up.

You could potentially see if you can caretake for an italian family's place while they vacation elsewhere. Some people do this to travel cheaply. They take care of pets/plants and get a free place to stay, a little spending money and maybe get to see areas less touristy AND access to a kitchen. I'm giving serious thought to doing that myself :)
Travel off season for cheaper rates. Use public transport and walk a lot!! there’s nothing wrong with being frugal. You don’t have to spend a lot of money to enjoy Italy.

I am totally budget conscious when I travel. I will pay for some things and bargain hunt for others. I prefer to book things on my own and use tours only when necessary. I don't generally dine in fine restaurants usually doing grab and go for lunch but will do a sit down dinner. I check menu's and prices first before I sit.
This is a great question!!
Dina Garrett BillandAngala Verley Julie Franco Mellow

Nothing ever wrong with wanting to save money. 😊 One of the biggest ways I try to save money is with food. I always book hotels that have breakfast included. Also, I always make sure my hotel has a mini frig and I frequent the local grocery stores and buy food for lunches and sometimes dinners. I also bring snacks from home, like granola bars, so if I need a snack I don’t have to spend money on that either.

So we are are a strict budget and although it would be great to get tickets to the main attractions, we like to walk the unbeaten paths. For instance in Naples we walked a little away from the touristy things and found the most amazing restaurants and shops. We did the same in Florence. We choose to enjoy the scenery and beauty of Italy instead of anything we had to pay to get into. We also had an airbnb which allowed us to cook for ourselves first thing in the morning and maybe sometimes in the evenings. Also, the airbnb is always centrally located so we don’t have to take a taxi everywhere. At restaurants I tend to want to order everything on the menu, we we learned to each order something different and we can share a little from each. I think this is what you were asking.
Following!

Eat where many Italian eat.
Eat italian.. its tasty and more cheap then steak or burgers.
Buy italian products in supermarket and not the imported brands you know.
Italian water is of good quality No need to buy cans.

Avoid eating in the city center. If you just wander out of the main centre you will find restaurants offering pranzo di lavoro (workers lunch) for like €12. This will include a pasta dish (primo) meat (sometimes fish if by sea) and vegetables (secondo + contorni) and coffee. Dessert and drinks are not normally included .
If Naples sorrento area the train goes all the way from Naples thru Hercaleneum, Pompeii to sorrento in under an hour one end to the other for a few euros
Don’t get a tour at Pompeii as you’ll miss most of it
A taxi driver in Hercaleneum took me to a local restaurant sun and moon I think and then in the way back went high so I could see the bay of Naples at night. No extra charge

Don't use middlemen (book everything directly)
Cook things yourself if possible (groceries in Italy is cheaper than France even in Supermercato)
Use public transport (and buy your ticket from tabaccheria as they sell them cheaper than on the bus)
I'm taking my partner as a surprise for his 50th and I'm soooo stressed I'm not going to have enough? 2 nights just outside milan. Planning on using public transport but any other tips welcome 😊

I have always relied on cheap hostels in Europe, and have had really good experiences there. If you are a solo traveler, it is absolutely the cheapest way to go. Even for a couple, you can get a private space for much less than a hotel. The communal aspect is fun, and sometimes hostels have tours, etc. ￼
Go down side streets to find local shops and restaurants of the beaten track.

I get it some people can be very nasty when it’s not necessary. What I do when I book a vacation I plan a year ahead and look for best deals. One Example I booked through vacation tour company almost 6 months before tour and saved $1,000. When I compared prices closed to tour it was $1,000 more and now for next year it’s $1,500. You just keep checking for price drops and discounts
Figure out the local bus or train schedule and stay outside the city on the route.
You can admire Roman Forum, Palatine Hill, Trajan’s market, and colosseum from the street without paying entrance fee unless you want to go inside
Totally agree!!!
Start reading on travel hacking; it'll save you tons of money on airfare and hotels.

text:
Hi everyone! My husband and I depart for Italy on 9/1 to celebrate our 25th anniversary...Rome, Tuscany and Amalfi coast. Our travel agent said that they can not get any private tours for the Roman Ruins or Colosseum on the Sunday we are in Rome (9/3) because they are doing a "free" day where everyone can get in. Is this true? Any other tour groups you trust that I can call and find something? We were leary of booking anything for 9/2 because it is our arrival day in the very early hours -plus we've had delays to Europe in past and missed a whole day-Already booked on 9/4 for the vatican and scavvi. We depart for Tuscany shortly thereafter.
We were considering just plugging through jet lag and walking over to both either on our arrival day or on the "free" day but figured it could be crazy!!
Next question is anyone familiar with Castello De Spaltenna in the Chianti region of Tuscany? That is where we are staying and I've heard mixed reviews on the restaurants on site. I've been told you can walk into town for nice restaurants but I'm not sure about the safety aspect of Gaiole and the roads leading in and out of town from our location. We do love to walk. What do you think about walking at night? We are doing a food and wine pairing one day and are going into florence another. On the other 2 days we plan to "relax and enjoy the castle, the grounds and the spa".

If you've been to this area can you please recommend restaurants in the town close by? Here is a picture of the castle/hotel.

Thank you!!!

And P.S. previous posts helped me select restaurants to book in
Rome and Sorrento. 💖

comments.comment_text: Every first Sunday of the month ALL museums are free throughout Italy including the Colosseum. Entry is on a first come first served basis.
We will be in Florence on 9/3 and it s been impossible to book anything. We are there for 2 days and a lot of the places are closed on Monday. Hopefully hotel comes thru with help!
Michelle Vincent read the comments
We arrived early am and did a midafternoon golf cart tour w an early dinner on our first day. It was a great way to get acclimated and also feel like we didn’t waste a day or over do it.

We are doing a golf cart tour and early dinner our first day as well. Glad to here that’s not a waste. Our travel agent booked it for us.

Good luck. Have fun and stay safe
Janice Foxcroft
We will be in Tuscany 9/3-9/6 and sorrento 9/6- 9/9 if you want to do any shared tours
Yes, Sunday is a free day at museums.

Plug through the first day if you can rather than waste the day. I find it best to resist the urge to take a nap on arrival/check in. Although you may not feel energized enough for a lot of walking or intense activity.

Maybe a guided driving or golf cart tour highlighting the major sights followed by a nice dinner with a view.

We arrived in Rome at 9:30 am, booked “Drivers in Rome” for our airport transfer and extended it to include a 2 hour driving tour hitting all the major sites. Checked into our airB&B at 3pm and then did a pasta making class from 6-9pm …. and then in bed by 11pm so that we weren’t too tired the next day.

Also wouldn’t recommend any very early morning activities the second day.

I would believe a travel agent they have no reason to give you misinformation.
Enjoy your trip!

I have been to Spaltenna it is a beautiful property. The road to Gaiole will be a dark country road with little to no shoulder. I would walk during the day but I would not recommend at night. Which restaurants are you considering in Gaiole?
First Sunday of the month is the free state-run museum day

We stayed at Castello De Spaltenna several years ago & found the food to be really good. They also had a Michelin Star restaurant on site which we had to ourselves one night.
You can walk down to the town but it’s quite steep & no footpath but certainly doable. A beautiful place to stay.
Would the Early Morning Vatican Breakfast Tour, be included in this Free Museum Day?
We have a tour booked on a Sunday for coliseum but Vatican is the free last Sunday of the month so no tours

We stayed at Castello De Spaltenna in September 2022. We loved it! And the food was amazing! We had a rental car and Gaiole in Chianti was close but for us not close enough to walk and we didn’t want to drive because of having to find parking so we ate at their indoor restaurant that also had a patio overlooking the pool every night and thought the food was amazing. We did not eat in their more expensive courtyard restaurant. We also went on a winery tour with a private driver and that was also amazing! Not sure when you read those reviews but I would recommend it highly! 😊

Would Sunday October 1st be the free day in Rome ? We will be there Saturday and Sunday Oct 7 and 8. Waiting on booking night Coloseum tour with Coopculture and don't want to waste the 8th if not possible and do other tours.
Unfortunately your travel agent didn’t do you any favours with your itinerary. We looked early and decided to use Sundays as travel days and made sure to avoid the first Sunday of the month.
Have a great time, I can’t believe my trip was 10 months ago and I am still in the post trip dream!

I was staying in a place similar in Cortona, Via De Piazzano. Long road into the town. I told my TA I wanted city center as we were not driving those roads or depending on taxis. I didn’t want to be stuck at their restaurant or feel like I was on their schedule for rides. We are arriving in Rome the week after you and did it this way to avoid closures.

http://
www.ristorodilam
ole.it/en/ highly recommended this restaurant for lunch, unbelievable food and service! And the views were amazing. Possibly one of the best eating experiences I’ve had 🙌

Lisa

The drive to lamole will be a experience. We have eaten there twice. Fantastic

I wish my kids had chose this place for their wedding! We’re a $40 cab ride to get to their venue from Florence — castle is lovely, but no amenities or towns within walking distance. I am not planning to drive myself, just use car service/cabs.
Check out Walks of Italy. Great tours.
Do the Golf cart tour the day you arrive. Plan for a 6 pm departure. Highlight of our time in Roma!!
1st Sunday of each month is free entrance in the Colosseo. We were there on a free Sunday. You just wait in line and get inside. I have no idea if they do tours however.
Try Joe Banana Limos..they are doing all our tours for next month.
I am going to Florence and Rome in October. I would love to know who you booked your wine tasting with in Tuscany? Thank you!
I was just in Rome and used this tour guide. She was awesome! She handled everything. Just showed up!

We have stayed there! It's absolutely breathtaking and the food and wine is exceptional! Very romantic setting, we did rent a car and visited the surrounding area and winery, I'm sure the hotel could help you with details! You'll love it!❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
can you share your itinerary? Days in each town? I’m considering these same places for my trip and cannot decide.
Yes the first Sunday of every month is free admittance on every monument or museum under the direct control of the ministry of culture

text:
Hi everyone! Will be traveling to Italy next week and have some questions, I hope you all can help me out.
1. For the colosseum, our coop culture tickets say to enter at the Valadier Gate. Can anyone tell me which side of the colosseum this is on? Don’t want to be too lost the day of 😅

2. We have tickets for the Accademia in Florence for the lastआणखी time on Tuesday at 9pm. We will be doing a whole day Tuscany trip earlier that day and will be coming back from that hopefully by 8pm (excursion says 11-12 hr duration). Does anyone have personal experience of how long this excursion was/what time you were back at the meeting point?
Would we be able to pick up tickets the day before at the Accademia if in case we won’t make it to the gallery by 8:45?

Link to the Tuscany day trip mentioned above:
Tuscany Day Trip from Florence: Siena, San Gimignano, Pisa and Lunch at a Winery
https://www.viator.com/search/5070TUSCANY?mcid=64243

Thank you in advance!

comments.comment_text: We did that exact excursion last week. We got back a little after 8p.
For coop culture tours, the meeting point is about here (red x). Get there a bit early and remember your passports, as they do check the names on tickets match!

text: I wondering smoothest way after a very long flight to Rome to get to city centre ? Uber? Limo ? Thank you

comments.comment_text: Train
Dario private tours and transportation service
I’ve used a private car through Viator.

I used the transfer company welcome pickups. I highly recommend them, clean and new vehicles and the drivers drive sensibly Welcome Pickups used then from and back to the airport, then again for our transfers in Malta
Train or taxi
Train
The taxi kiosk is right outside the airport exit. It is a flat fee to the city. (I don’t remember how much. Maybe 40 euro.)
Leonardo Express shuttle train to Roma Termini train station, then taxi.
Cabs are best and easiest way right outside the terminal. Set 50 euro price.
Our Airbnb host offered to organise a taxi, who was waiting as we came out of Arrivals. As there were 5 of us it was cheaper than the train, and was direct to our accommodation.
Air B and B host got us transportation to our rental!
Take the Leonardo Express train. 11 euros. Leaves often. Enjoy!
Taxi. There is a stand right outside airport
We have been to Rome multiple times, and we have a regular private driver. Wonderful guy. Speaks English. Reliable. Reasonable price. Nice to have a friend in Rome.
Was just there and it’s a flat rate of 45 euros from airport to city centre.
The train to Roma Termini then a taxi or walk!
Dario Private Tour and Transportation Service
Smoothest would be private transfer next would be cab

Their official website is in Italian (no link that I can see to switch to an English version), so I’m a bit lost in translation so to speak.

Can I get an English audio headset or tour once inside ?

I’ve seen some skip the line tickets via the usual agents but I’d like to buy direct from the official website.

Any advice would be much appreciated TIA 🙂

comments.comment_text: I've been there once on a school trip as a teacher but it is mainly visited for the view from the rooftop. It is a wonderful view, though

text: Anyone with experience with Firenze Hotel Number Nine? Good/bad???

comments.comment_text: Sorry never heard if it. I always recommend Hotel David. Charming, great breakfast and happy hour included. Book thru the hotel directly. Been there at at least 30 times.
We LOVED it. Rooms were lovely, location was great. Staff was super helpful. We felt very pampered!

text: Long shot - in 2005, Rick Steves recommended lunch spot in Bellagio had the best house wine (literally didn't have bottles) and amazing ragu. Down an alley. Any ideas?

comments.comment_text: You may want to ask this question to RS’s Forum and see if anyone can confirm it

text:
Thank you for all the wonderful posts that are invaluable for planning our 1st trip to Italy. We will be relying mainly on trains for our transport. Am just a bit confused if I have the correct order (around Venice, Cinque Terre, Florence) that is best for time length on trains. Flying into Milan, leaving from Rome.
Lakes area
Venice
Verona
Cinque Terra
Florence
Naples
Sorrento
Rome
Many Thanks

comments.comment_text: Fly into Venice and you will be in perfect shape for travel, Milan makes no sense logistics wise. If, however, you are committed to Milan, go lakes area to Venice, train to Verona and on to CT. Train back to Florence to Naples.

We flew into Milan then went to Venice but Verona is closer if you planned that. Then from Venice we went to Florence, Rome, Naples then took a car to sorrento and then back to Naples Airport picked up a rent a car and drove to Bari.
Fly into Venice Marco Polo, then you can take a bus or train that would take you to Venezia Santa Lucia.

In this order if your flying from Milan, Florence, cinque Terre( we were just there 2days ago and did not like it at all) no comparison from Amalfi coast and Positano) Venice, train to Verona, fly or take a train to Rome, train or drive to Sorrento, train or drive to Naples then fly out to Rome. We are doing the opposite of your trip. We flew from Rome, stay 2 days, Flew to Venice skip Verona— train to Florence, went to cinque Terre our base is Florence then we’re flying out to Milan.

text: Staying in Sorrento in middle of September. We are wanting to take the ferry to Positano and Almalfi in one day. Is it better to buy the ferry ticket the day before or should I buy them online now? I have read comments about the ferries canceling or the times being off from purchased times online. Any recommendations?

comments.comment_text: on the day or day before
last September in Amalfi... enjoy xxx
Just go on the day
Day before
Wait. You never know what the weather and the seas will be like.
Following
We did it when we got there
In September I’m flying into ROME and taking the train to Salerno for one night then ferry to Positano 🇮🇹
We purchased day of…no issues
Due to the unforeseen weather, they won’t sell in advance. If they sell you the day before, that’s great. But we usually show up early and purchase tickets in the morning weather permitting
We will be doing the same thing next month. Plan to buy in the morning
I’m trying to decide to do this exact thing on my own, or if I should be getting a shared boat tour to these places, any thoughts from any one who has done it? Early Oct 🙂
Wait, the schedules and weather can change.
We took a ferry from Sorrento to Amalfi and then took the bus to Positano. The bus is such a fun ride!
In the middle of September you will be fine to buy the day of. No worries!

text: Hi! I need things to do for these days in Europe! Please leave all your recommendations 🫶🏻

comments.comment_text: Google?
La spezia. Get the ferry around cinque terre
La Spezia 100% visit a couple of Cinque Terre towns. You can catch the train, sometimes the ferry doesn’t run due to weather.
Cliff jumping Majorca so much fun 🤗🤗
For Naples- look into going to the Amalfi coast! We haven’t gone yet but that’s what we’re doing next month when we stop there on our cruise. I’ve heard good things and it looks stunning!

We did this same cruise but Rome was our home port. In Barcelona we did a city tour, Palma we did a city tour as well, la Spezia we did cinque terre boat tour, Naples we did Amalfi Coast and Pompeii, and Marseille we did a city tour as well.
Are these places only for 1 day?? That's nuts! I guess I'd just walk around.
Following
If it's a cruise I wouldn't chance going too far off course as you don't want to miss your boat back! Walk around Italy is full of history..

The port in Rome is over an hour's travel time to Rome itself, even by taxi. Could be closer to 2 hours by public transport, so you will probably need to choose just one area to concentrate on. Colosseum always interesting but best to try to buy advance tickets as queues can be very long. From there metro and short walk takes you to sights like trevi fountain, pantheon, all close together. Hop on and off bus tour would give you view of most sights, and some time to just wander if you prefer to see as much as you can. Just don't miss your boat! Have fun😀

Portovenere might be a good option for LaSpezia - might be less crowded and offers a good deal of the flavor of Cinque Terre and that actually may well be where you get the ferry/cruise up the coast to see the 5 villages from the sea - one of the most picturesque places on the planet.

If I may comment on Barcelona, La Sagrada Familia inside and outside if you can do it - you most likely need to purchase advance tickets to skip the line but worth it. Park Guell would also be high on the list. Just returned from a week In Barcelona with 2 adult children, their spouses and a 9-year-old - Tibidabo was one of their favorite spots. You have a lovely itinerary in your future. Montserrat is also an interesting option from Barcelona. Barcelona also has a nice Picasso museum if you are into art.
Good Luck & safe travels!!! 😍😍

text: Hello..I’m in Rome right now with friends. What’s the easiest way to travel from Roma Termini to Assissi?

comments.comment_text: A regional train, takes around 2 hours

text: Looking to purchase tickets for the night tour of the coliseum. The website is not giving me any dates. Suggestions? We hope to go sept 16

comments.comment_text:
Where will you be in September. Jack and I are going to be in Italy until September 20th.
Try Viatour

Pretty darn much!! Hate the tell you but...August is the worst month to visit Italy!!

Super hot, steamy weather, AC is sketchy depending where you are. Yes. Many restaurants, theaters, galleries, events either close down or limit times!

fect weather and, near Christmas, amazingly beautiful!!

text: For families with young children, how did you travel around Italy? We are planning to catch trains between major cities for transfer between train stations and accomodation, is it better to book private transfer with car seat? Do taxi come with car seat? Would you recommend hiring a car instead for the 14 day trip?

comments.comment_text: Trains are fine. Just minimize what you haul around. Always have the children with you when you enter the train. I have heard of people loading luggage while putting the kid in and the train taking off before they could get on. (No joke) Taxis do not come with car seats. Having a car has its pros and cons. Cons are parking in the cities. You will have a difficult time finding it and that would mean having to walk (sometimes with luggage) extra distances to get where you need because you may have to park outside the city centers.

text:
My partner and I are hoping to spend 3 months in Italy next year. We would like to spend a month in the north, 1 month in the Tuscany area ( or center part of the country) and 1 month in the south. Very interested in the east side of the country on the Adriatic Sea? Would like to be off the beaten track but also catch the top sites in each area asआणखी well.
Any ideas and input would be greatly appreciated.
Best time of year to be there for that length of time? Possibly skiing in the dolomite’s?
Renting homes or Airbnb and how to find?
Heard there are more beautiful places than Positano and less crowded? Really?
How to apply for the new visa for next year?
Thank you

comments.comment_text:
Ortisei in the Dolomites area was right off a post card. If you enjoy nature, that whole area is beautiful. Check out Cortina d’Ampezzo as well.
In the east San Marino and Urbino are both worth a visit. There are many nice towns in Puglia. Vieste is a bit out of the way but a great seaside town.
In Calabria, Tropea is great and Scilla is worth a day trip. If you really want to get off the beaten path, visit Stilo, Squillace, Gerace, Bova. Very little English spoken in that region.
Good luck; should be a great trip!

On airbnb and Vrbo there are apartments for one month stay.
If you want to ski start in march in the north, but I wouldn’t stay 1 month in the mountain (unless you really want to ski a lot!). Beautiful places are Selva di Val Gardena, Ortisei, Madonna di Campiglio, San Cassiano… a way to choose can be looking at Dolomiti super-ski pass and see which cities covers: you’ll have 1000 km of slopes in one ticket.
Nice places where to spend a month can be Bolzano, Parma, Turin (you’ll also have Courmayeur not far to go skiing), Crema, Pavia.
In Tuscany in April the whether can be great, with the spring blooming, Florence, Siena and Lucca are all nice choices (Lucca and Siena easier) but also a smaller town like Pisa, well linked with trains and a small airport that can take you to Sicily with cheap flights.
I would add a week in Rome.
In the south in may starts the really good season, still not touristy and not too hot. Look for Lecce and it’s surroundings, or if you want by the sea look for Polignano a mare or Otranto.

As to your visa question — it is not a visa, it is a travel authorization that goes into effect sometime i. 2024. Date not yet announced. You can get all the information here.

https://
etias.com/

Wow! Thank you all for the great info! So very helpful and I definitely have some work to do😅, but with these recommendations
, I’m off to a good start!
As another option, would September October and November have good weather? Starting in the south instead? But wonder if there’s snow for a little skiing!
You’re correct that a month of that would be too long.
Also forgot to ask about the lake Como area. I’ve seen posts about other lakes near there that are even nicer

Good on you for taking such a long time! Will you go to Sicily? The west coast is great, and Syracuse is brilliant.
Reggio Calabria has a really good archaeological museum. We used Bari as a base in Puglia and it was easy to use public transport to get to Monopoli or Polignano. We didn’t manage to get to Matera but it’s supposed to be stunning.
I’d alternate between the big cities and smaller ones. We really liked Padua, Parma and Ferrara.
I’m not convinced that the other lakes are nicer than Como. We’ve been to Varenna twice. If you are fit, it’s much cheaper to stay in Perledo. It’s up a hill and there are paths off the road. Or Fiumelatte is nice too.
I spent two full weeks in Rome years ago and I think it’s really worth it to find all the different places. I’m not Catholic but I loved going to a full mass in St Peters. Just make sure you don’t accidentally go on a special day! I went on Holy Thursday and it was over two hours 😂

Definitely for Rome daytime highs will still be 80+ (I just checked the long range forecast). Your plan sounds pretty good. Outerwear needs will depend how early/late you will be out and about. Last time I was in the Tuscany region around the same time I think I only saw one day of light rain that was somewhat limited. Just so happened to be the day we were at a local market.

Melissa Pope , we’re going to Rome, Florence and Venice at the same time but are staying 14 days. I’m just going to wait and check the weather the week before so we will have a better and more accurate view of the weather as to what to pack .
Still hot 80's during the day. Cool at night 50-60's
Thank you Everyone!
It’s not a third world country folks. More fun to buy a few things you may need while there❤️

It’s still very warm. We were there same time last year staying in Montepulciano and swam every day. Light dresses and shorts and have the blazer to throw on if you need it. Linen pants. Humidity should break while you’re there or just before and you’ll have perfect weather with clear skies and no haze.

I've got my wardrobe picked out. It's not extensive, and I'm taking a sweater, poncho, hoodie on the plane, but mostly short pants and tees. Future forecasts are just estimates, but looks like low to mid 80s for highs and a little cooler at night (60s).

Clothes that don’t wrinkle easily , pack light and pack or wear your most comfortable pair of sneakers . I had my feet measured at a sneaker shop referred to by my orthopedic surgeon. Your feet will thank you later . I’ve been traveling to Italy since I was 5 ( mom born in Florence Italy and I have family in Rome and other towns ) and I’m almost 65. So I’ve done a lot of walking on cobblestone streets .
I would not bring any blazers. I outer garment plus rain jacket, a couple pairs of light pants and couple dresses.

I suggest choosing your essentials nearer the time as the weather forecast this year is crazy! The wettest June followed by the hottest July on record, and these last few days have been windy and rainy so the temperature has dropped again. The forecast is that by the end of this week it will be very hot again (I’m in the Naples bay / Amalfi coast), but hard to forecast one month ahead.
Also, geographically it’s unlikely you’ll get similar weather in Rome and Venice for example…
Light layers and comfy shoes are always a good idea though and your list sounds about right 😊

It will be warm , if it is the same as last September,Octob
er. Don’t take the world , as u have to carry it . I go every year & I take two pairs of good sneakers ( very comfortable) one leather pair of sandals. A few long cotton dresses, pants, silk tops. I only travel with cotton, linen , silk + a jacket/
cardigan, silk scarf, if u need some thing they have the best shopping 🌻
Cobblestone streets are very difficult to walk with sandals, your feet will twist
The weather was in 70 ‘s . But it rained on & off

text: Question - we are currently planning to spend 4 nights and 3 full days in Rome and then 3 nights in Pitigliano before heading to Cinque Terre and onward for a total of 19 nights in Italy. I’m starting to wonder if it would make more sense to add a night to Rome and take one away from Pitigliano. Any thoughts?

comments.comment_text:
it depends on what you want to do in Pitigliano. it is a small town, at 9km you can see Sorano and at the same distance Sovana.
But you can also go trekking to the "Vie Cave", Etruscan-era roads carved into the rock, go to Saturnia Bath (about 30min by car), horse trekking or horse riding (it’s beautiful in this area).
It’s a very relaxing area. If you want relax and enjoy Maremma countryside it’s perfect.
keep in mind that you must have your own car to get around, because public transport in this area is very bad.

If you need more info, ask me. I was born here 😉
I would definitely add another day to Rome so much more to see in Rome.
I think two nights would be plenty. It's my very favorite Tuscan village. A half day for Pitigliano. A half for Civita di Bagnoregio. A full day for Orvieto.

Try opening an account with Charles Schwab and use the debit card linked to your checking account with Schwab. It worked great for us in Europe. We were able to get cash at the airport.￼

We exchange a few hundred at the airport. Exchange rate isn’t really that much more, and it’s a lot easier. After that, we use bank ATMs in Europe. Make sure they are attached to a bank, though, and not the ones that are just on the street. ￼
Chase bank ordered euros for me last month when I traveled. It took a few days..so plan ahead.
ATM
If you can’t get at your CU, I would get at a bank atm in Italy. Make sure it’s an ATM at a bank and not a random ATM on the street. (I got that recommendation on this page. Lower fees!)
Get them from my bank. Not a problem
Bank or AAA have low fees
ATM 🏧 from banks
We had to order Euro’s from the bank. They didn’t come in until after we left so we bought some at the airport.

NEVER get euros before your trip! there are ATMs everywhere, be sure your bank doesn't charge fees for using other bank's ATM machines. you will get the best rate at a local ATM, buying euros in the US will cost a lot and no need!
You have to order from banks probably. I was lucky and found out a chase in the area had them on hand
Get your cash when you arrive. There are atm’s everywhere!

get euros from local ATM machines! fast, easy ... if your bank charges a fee for using other banks' ATMs, raise the limit you can withdraw, tho you shouldn't need much cash. there is NO need to get euros before your trip
No need for euros before you go. Banks everywhere. Use atm at a bank. Super easy.
This is probably a dumb question but I don't use ATM machines here in the US, but I have a card through my bank. Do I just use my bank
I get it from bank atm in Europe. Just make sure you know your banks foreign transactions fees.
is there any euro exchange from the airport?
We had to order
Never get currency before you go. Use your ATM when you are there if you need cash. But best just to use your credit card everywhere. Your card will always give you the best exchange
Get them in italy
Chase bank & u can pu in 2 days

Ask your friends or local neighborhood FB page. People with some leftover after a trip will give you a great exchange rate.

We get euros at a bank ATM after landing.
ATM at destination. You'll get the bank rate less the exorbitant exchange fees.
You can order them from your local AAA office. May have to be a member to do this.
Most international airports will have a currency exchange office. Not the best rate but convenient. Check for hours of operation.
We use a kiosk at our mall. They have the best prices. CXI currency exchange international. Usually can get Euros same day
I always order from the bank. It is the best rate & you get them in a day or two.
Mark Clemens

I prefer getting from Chase bank prior to the trip. You get to decide on your bills (small, mixed or large) and you can take as much as you want out. At an ATM, you might have a daily 24hr limit. I am not risking that when I need cash for specific daily excursions. I also want the small bills. So it can depend on how much you need daily if the ATM will work for you. There’s still a few to withdraw from the ATM.

Go to a larger bank. Most will require you to have at least a savings account there. I just put the minimum in to open a savings account and got my money through them. Whatever I brought back in over 250 was exchanged at no fee

BANK affiliated ATM’s but make sure it’s bank affiliated - you can do the transaction in English and it (in my experience) will ask you to confirm the fee - if it is more than a few dollars more than your regular ATM fee in the US it probably is not bank affiliated. I’ve been burned twice on free-standing ATMs. Sometimes hotels will have bank affiliated machines in their lobbies - just pay attention to the part of the transaction that asks you to accept the fee😊
ATM at your destination but not at the airport. They charge higher fees.
AAA

In my experience I have ALWAYS gotten euros from my bank in the US - allow a week, doesn’t cost a lot, & when you arrive & you are trying to navigate everything & you are tired, it’s nice not to have to worry about finding an ATM. That’s my opinion & experience. That said I only start with say 300-500 euros max. I use my international credit card (no fees) & save my euros for small things like tips, taxis, etc. If I decide I need more euros, I go to a bank ATM (not just a random one) that is a universal/
network one (that will be on your ATM card which ones are universal/
network). There will likely be a small fee, but it is not much & it’s part of the cost of international travel.

comments.comment_text: I thought the winding roads were making me carsick .. not the ferry.. but weather could make a difference

Naples to sorrento during the heatwave was still very rocky but didn’t feel dangerous.

Potisano to sorrento and Capri to sorrento return less rocky

I get motion sick quite easily. When I took the ferry from Amalfi to Capri I went upstairs on the outside deck. I did try to stay downstairs in the enclosed portion of the boat but I felt sick almost immediately, plus I could smell the fumes from the fuel. Ugh! Being outside was the key for me - and I wore sea bands - it’s an acupressure thing. Made a difference on both the ferry and the winding roads. Good luck and have a fabulous trip!

I’ve just left Capri and Amalfi coast and didn’t find the ferry’s too rocky or rough, only a little bit. The ferry from Naples to Capri was nowhere near as bad as it has been made out to be (but was still slightly rocky) and the ferry from Capri to Amalfi coast was about the same.

I usually always get motion sickness on boats so I took travel sickness tablets before each ferry and I didn’t feel unwell at all. You can get motion sickness tablets at any pharmacy in Italy and they’re not too expensive.

I wore sea bands on the Sorrento to Positano, Amalfi ferry. The crew was passing out bags to everyone. My husband-he has never had a problem on boats-got seasick and felted bad all day long. Even with the sea bands I felt a bit queasy. Inquired about taking a car service back to Sorrento, but people said it could be worse with the winding roads. We opted for not eating anything all day, and buying Dramamine at the Farmicia-took the ferry back. There was a long line to get the meds! They also sold us ginger crews that somewhat helped. It was also really hot. Hope this helps!
Pack some Bonine just in case.
I brought Dramamine with me and never needed it. I was on several ferries on different days.
So are the ferries worse that private boat options from Sorrento to Capri due to fumes? Sometimes the fumes are my ultimate trigger.

Is it always rough?
We are going to Amalfi in Sept. We live in Mass and take ferry’s to Nantucket and Martha’s Vineyard with no problem. Hoping it’s the same.
Just get a prescription for the anti-sea sickness patches before you leave. Be sure to put on according to directions. I think it says 4 hours prior to departure.

If your family get sick, then I think you've answered your own question. Skip Almalfi it's over rated and hard to get around and incredibly hilly with crappy beaches. Go to Tuscany, Cinque Terre is so much better and accessible by train. Amalfi looks great in a postcard only.

I was ok on the short ferries (sorrento/
Capri, sorrento/
positano, tour of capri) BUT do NOT visit the blue grotto by boat if you get seasick. WORST 2 hours of my year. You have to wait ON the boat from the rowboat to come get you. People vomiting all over the ferry and I felt soooo sick it ruined my entire day
Leslie Mackie-General Dave General
I found that regular anti acids work great and are less expensive than motion sickness tablets. Most people already have Tums or Rolaids on them.
